pages.raw_output:
<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 118, 378, 144]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSE™  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 171, 183, 187]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 194, 365, 210]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 Multiple Choice (Extended)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 171, 905, 230]]<|/det|>
0625/22 May/June 2025 45 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 247, 506, 263]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 278, 540, 322]]<|/det|>
You will need: Multiple choice answer sheet Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 338, 226, 352]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 354, 905, 520]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions.- For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D. Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Follow the instructions on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Write in soft pencil.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the multiple choice answer sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.- Do not use correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- Take the weight of \(1.0 \text{kg}\) to be \(9.8 \text{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 9.8 \text{m/s}^2\)).  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 548, 218, 562]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 564, 570, 610]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- Each correct answer will score one mark.- Any rough working should be done on this question paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 96, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 897, 90]]<|/det|>
Which instrument is most suitable to determine the volume of a small irregularly shaped stone?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 101, 248, 117]]<|/det|>
**A** 30 cm ruler

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 127, 250, 142]]<|/det|>
**B** digital timer

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 153, 312, 168]]<|/det|>
**C** measuring cylinder

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 179, 270, 194]]<|/det|>
**D** tape measure

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 222, 96, 240]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 222, 805, 240]]<|/det|>
A steel ball is dropped from the top floor of a building. Air resistance can be ignored.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 253, 529, 269]]<|/det|>
Which statement describes the motion of the ball?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 281, 484, 297]]<|/det|>
**A** The ball falls with constant acceleration.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 308, 432, 323]]<|/det|>
**B** The ball falls with constant speed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 334, 453, 349]]<|/det|>
**C** The ball falls with decreasing speed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 360, 495, 375]]<|/det|>
**D** The ball falls with increasing acceleration.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 404, 96, 422]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 404, 749, 421]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a velocity–time graph for an object which is accelerating.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[292, 432, 702, 692]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 706, 435, 722]]<|/det|>
What is the acceleration of the object?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 733, 732, 750]]<|/det|>
**A** \(0.40m / s^{2}\) **B** \(2.5m / s^{2}\) **C** \(3.0m / s^{2}\) **D** \(100m / s^{2}\)

Diagram 2 shows the same piece of flexible material after it has been compressed so that its volume decreases. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[267, 115, 725, 255]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 269, 870, 286]]<|/det|> What happens to the mass and to the weight of the flexible material when it is compressed? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 300, 457, 426]]<|/det|>
massweight

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 454, 94, 473]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 454, 477, 471]]<|/det|> A student determines the density of copper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 485, 440, 501]]<|/det|> She has a rectangular block of copper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 515, 444, 531]]<|/det|> Which other apparatus does she need? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 543, 725, 670]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 700, 94, 718]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 700, 542, 717]]<|/det|> A 0.15kg mass is suspended from a vertical spring. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 730, 918, 763]]<|/det|> The mass is pulled downwards until the spring has extended by 12cm from its unstretched length. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 776, 480, 792]]<|/det|> The spring constant of the spring is \(30N / m.\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 806, 783, 822]]<|/det|> What is the magnitude of the initial acceleration of the spring when it is released? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 833, 722, 850]]<|/det|> A \(14m / s^{2}\) B \(24m / s^{2}\) C \(28m / s^{2}\) D \(34m / s^{2}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 96, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 621, 90]]<|/det|> A cricket ball of mass \(0.15 \mathrm{kg}\) is moving at a speed of \(30 \mathrm{m / s}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 918, 135]]<|/det|> The diagram shows a batsman holding a bat stationary as the ball hits the bat and bounces back at the same speed in the opposite direction. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 149, 517, 165]]<|/det|> The ball is in contact with the bat for \(1.0 \times 10^{- 3} \text{s}\). <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[303, 175, 692, 303]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 317, 918, 349]]<|/det|> The table shows the change in momentum of the ball and the magnitude of the force applied to the ball. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 363, 297, 378]]<|/det|> Which row is correct? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 392, 596, 536]]<|/det|>
change of momentum
kg m/s		force applied to ball/N
A4.54500
B4.59000

D9.09000
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 565, 96, 583]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 565, 600, 581]]<|/det|> A stone is thrown vertically upwards at a speed of \(5.0 \text{m/s}\) . <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 596, 918, 626]]<|/det|> All of the energy initially in the kinetic store of the stone is transferred to its gravitational potential store when the stone reaches its maximum height. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 641, 672, 657]]<|/det|> Which equation gives the maximum height \(h\) reached by the stone? <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 670, 260, 705]]<|/det|> \[\mathbf{A}\quad h = \frac{9.8}{2\times 5.0^2}\] <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 718, 260, 752]]<|/det|> \[\mathbf{B}\quad h = \frac{5.0^2\times 2}{9.8}\] <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 766, 255, 800]]<|/det|> \[\mathbf{C}\quad h = \frac{5.0^2}{2\times 9.8}\] <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 813, 255, 847]]<|/det|> \[\mathbf{D}\quad h = \frac{2\times 9.8}{5.0^2}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 97, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 402, 90]]<|/det|> Three energy resources are listed. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 103, 321, 120]]<|/det|> 1 geothermal <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 130, 267, 145]]<|/det|> 2 wind <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 155, 325, 171]]<|/det|> 3 nuclear fuel <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 184, 514, 201]]<|/det|> 
Which resources get their energy from the Sun?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 212, 707, 230]]<|/det|>
1, 2 and 3 B 1 and 2 only C 1 only D 2 only

D solid and liquid only

When the flask is gently warmed, the mercury rises up the tube. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[371, 421, 625, 668]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 680, 588, 696]]<|/det|> What is the main cause of the movement of the mercury? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 708, 136, 726]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 708, 380, 725]]<|/det|> expansion of air in the flask <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 735, 134, 753]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 735, 384, 752]]<|/det|> expansion of the glass flask <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 762, 134, 780]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 762, 380, 778]]<|/det|> expansion of the glass tube <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 789, 134, 806]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 789, 364, 805]]<|/det|> expansion of the mercury

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 919, 106]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the equipment used in an experiment to determine the specific heat capacity of a metal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 120, 920, 151]]<|/det|>
In the experiment, a heater is switched on for \(t\mathrm{s}\) and the increase in temperature \(\Delta \theta\) of a block of the metal is measured in \(^\circ \mathrm{C}\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[257, 163, 737, 365]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 377, 620, 394]]<|/det|>
Which equation gives the specific heat capacity of the metal?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 409, 730, 440]]<|/det|>
A \(c = \frac{P}{tm\Delta\theta}\) B \(c = \frac{Pt}{m\Delta\theta}\) C \(c = \frac{tm\Delta\theta}{P}\) D \(c = \frac{m\Delta\theta}{Pt}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 106, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 677, 90]]<|/det|> The diagram shows four rods. Each rod is made of a different metal. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[329, 100, 668, 324]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 338, 692, 355]]<|/det|> Wax is used to attach small metal balls at the rod ends P, Q, R and S. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 368, 811, 385]]<|/det|> Each rod is the same size. They are heated uniformly by a Bunsen burner at point X. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 399, 583, 415]]<|/det|> As the rods warm up, the wax melts and the balls fall off. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 429, 479, 445]]<|/det|> Why does the ball on the silver rod fall first? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 457, 445, 473]]<|/det|> **A** Silver is the best conductor of heat. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 484, 452, 499]]<|/det|> **B** Silver is the worst conductor of heat. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 510, 432, 525]]<|/det|> **C** Silver is the best radiator of heat. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 536, 435, 551]]<|/det|> **D** Silver is the worst radiator of heat. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 580, 107, 597]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 580, 751, 596]]<|/det|> Three solid copper spheres, X, Y and Z, are heated to the same temperature. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[300, 610, 700, 711]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>21</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 664, 90]]<|/det|>
A ray of light, travelling in air, is incident on an air–glass boundary.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 806, 120]]<|/det|>
The angles between the incident ray, the refracted ray and the boundary are shown.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[348, 129, 645, 260]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 273, 698, 291]]<|/det|>
Which equation is used to calculate the refractive index \(n\) of the glass?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 308, 744, 338]]<|/det|>
A \(n = \frac{\sin 40^{\circ}}{\sin 26^{\circ}}\) B \(n = \frac{\sin 40^{\circ}}{\sin 64^{\circ}}\) C \(n = \frac{\sin 50^{\circ}}{\sin 26^{\circ}}\) D \(n = \frac{\sin 50^{\circ}}{\sin 64^{\circ}}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 370, 107, 388]]<|/det|>
<label>22</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 370, 846, 387]]<|/det|>
A small object O is placed near a converging lens, as shown. The lens forms an image I.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[327, 396, 665, 530]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 543, 349, 560]]<|/det|>
Which statement is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 572, 372, 590]]<|/det|>
A The image I is diminished.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 600, 350, 617]]<|/det|>
B The image I is inverted.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 628, 315, 644]]<|/det|>
C The image I is real.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 654, 617, 670]]<|/det|>
D The object O is closer to the lens than its principal focus.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 699, 107, 715]]<|/det|>
<label>23</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 699, 491, 715]]<|/det|>
What is the approximate speed of light in air?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 727, 225, 743]]<|/det|>
A \(300m / s\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 753, 235, 769]]<|/det|>
B \(300km / s\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 780, 265, 796]]<|/det|>
C \(3.0\times 10^{8}m / s\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 806, 275, 822]]<|/det|>
D \(3.0\times 10^{8}km / s\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>24</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 780, 90]]<|/det|>
A ship sends an ultrasound pulse to the seabed to measure the depth of the sea.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 103, 588, 120]]<|/det|>
The speed of ultrasound waves in sea water is \(1500 \text{m/s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 133, 718, 150]]<|/det|>
The pulse takes 4.6 seconds to travel to the seabed and back to the ship.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 163, 361, 180]]<|/det|>
What is the depth of the sea?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 191, 717, 208]]<|/det|>
A \(330 \text{m}\) B \(650 \text{m}\) C \(3500 \text{m}\) D \(6900 \text{m}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 236, 107, 254]]<|/det|>
<label>25</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 236, 648, 253]]<|/det|>
A dolphin has a range of audible frequencies of 150 Hz–150 kHz.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 266, 892, 283]]<|/det|>
Which range of frequencies can be heard both by humans with good hearing and by dolphins?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 294, 270, 310]]<|/det|>
A \(20 \text{Hz}–150 \text{Hz}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 320, 280, 336]]<|/det|>
B \(20 \text{Hz}–150 \text{kHz}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 346, 287, 362]]<|/det|>
C \(20 \text{kHz}–150 \text{kHz}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 373, 278, 389]]<|/det|>
D \(150 \text{Hz}–20 \text{kHz}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 418, 107, 435]]<|/det|>
<label>26</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 418, 918, 450]]<|/det|>
A positively charged balloon is placed against a wall. The charge makes the balloon stick to the wall.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 463, 375, 479]]<|/det|>
Which statement explains this?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 491, 641, 507]]<|/det|>
A Positive charges on the balloon attract electrons in the wall.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 517, 628, 533]]<|/det|>
B Positive charges on the balloon attract protons in the wall.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 543, 628, 559]]<|/det|>
C Positive charges on the balloon repel electrons in the wall.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 570, 618, 585]]<|/det|>
D Positive charges on the balloon repel protons in the wall.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 613, 107, 631]]<|/det|>
<label>27</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 613, 907, 630]]<|/det|>
A student is trying to determine the resistance of a lamp. He sets up the incorrect circuit shown.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[393, 641, 602, 744]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 757, 920, 789]]<|/det|>
Which change would allow him to take the measurements needed to calculate the resistance of the lamp?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 800, 140, 817]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 800, 640, 817]]<|/det|>
Disconnect the ammeter and move it to the left of the lamp.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 827, 697, 843]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 823, 697, 841]]<|/det|>
Swap the positions of the ammeter and the voltmeter in the circuit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 852, 680, 868]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 850, 680, 867]]<|/det|>
Disconnect the ammeter and connect it in parallel with the lamp.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 878, 683, 894]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 877, 683, 894]]<|/det|>
Disconnect the voltmeter and connect it in parallel with the lamp.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 109, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 401, 88]]<|/det|> A metallic wire X has a resistance. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 764, 119]]<|/det|> What is the difference in resistance for a wire of the same material as X that is: <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 133, 534, 149]]<|/det|> ● shorter than X but the same diameter <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 160, 638, 175]]<|/det|> ● the same length as X but with a smaller diameter? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 187, 585, 333]]<|/det|>
resistance of shorter wireresistance of wire with smaller diameter
Agreatergreater
Bgreatersmaller
Csmallergreater
Dsmallersmaller
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 362, 107, 378]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 362, 547, 378]]<|/det|> The diagram shows the circuit for a potential divider. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[376, 388, 621, 547]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 559, 445, 575]]<|/det|> Which equation is used to calculate \(V_{1}\) ? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 590, 141, 610]]<|/det|> <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 588, 325, 624]]<|/det|> \[V_{1} = \frac{R_{1}}{V_{2}\times(R_{1} + R_{2})}\] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 640, 141, 660]]<|/det|> <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 636, 267, 672]]<|/det|> \[V_{1} = \frac{V_{2}\times R_{1}}{R_{2}}\] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 688, 141, 710]]<|/det|> <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 686, 270, 721]]<|/det|> \[V_{1} = \frac{V_{2}\times R_{1}}{R_{1} + R_{2}}\] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 740, 141, 763]]<|/det|> <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 740, 270, 775]]<|/det|> \[V_{1} = \frac{R_{1}}{V_{2}\times R_{2}}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>30</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 559, 90]]<|/det|>
Which electrical device is used to convert a.c. to d.c.?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 101, 201, 117]]<|/det|>
**A** diode

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 128, 196, 143]]<|/det|>
**B** relay

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 154, 239, 169]]<|/det|>
**C** thermistor

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 180, 252, 195]]<|/det|>
**D** transformer

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 225, 107, 243]]<|/det|>
<label>31</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 225, 919, 258]]<|/det|>
A cell is connected to a parallel combination of a \(2.0 \Omega\) resistor and a \(4.0 \Omega\) resistor. The current in the \(4.0 \Omega\) resistor is \(1.0 \text{A}\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[411, 269, 586, 432]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 448, 370, 464]]<|/det|>
What is the current in the cell?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 475, 700, 492]]<|/det|>
**A** 1.0A **B** 1.5A **C** 2.0A **D** 3.0A

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>32</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 919, 106]]<|/det|>
When there is an electric current in a long straight wire, a magnetic field is created around the wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 117, 919, 150]]<|/det|>
Which diagram shows the correct pattern and direction of magnetic field lines around a long straight wire carrying current into the page?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[138, 160, 858, 549]]<|/det|>
<center>key </center>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 575, 107, 593]]<|/det|>
<label>33</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 575, 919, 607]]<|/det|>
The primary voltage supplied to a transformer is 3.0V. The secondary voltage is 5.0V and the secondary current is 2.0A. The transformer is \(100\%\) efficient.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 619, 501, 636]]<|/det|>
What is the primary current in the transformer?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 648, 697, 666]]<|/det|>
A 1.2A B 2.0A C 3.3A D 7.5A

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 694, 107, 712]]<|/det|>
<label>34</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 694, 919, 727]]<|/det|>
When a thin gold foil is bombarded with alpha particles, some alpha particles are deflected through large angles.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 740, 460, 756]]<|/det|>
Which statement explains this deflection?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 769, 149, 787]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 769, 500, 786]]<|/det|>
Most of the atom consists of empty space.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 795, 140, 813]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 795, 919, 826]]<|/det|>
All of the positive charge and most of the mass of the gold atom are concentrated in a small volume.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 835, 139, 853]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 835, 732, 853]]<|/det|>
Positive charge in the gold atom is spread evenly throughout the atom.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 862, 141, 880]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 862, 600, 880]]<|/det|>
All of the negative charge is concentrated at its centre.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 109, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>35</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 754, 90]]<|/det|>
A detector near a radioactive source shows a reading of 2000 counts/minute.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 104, 485, 120]]<|/det|>
How is the corrected count rate determined?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 132, 510, 149]]<|/det|>
A by moving the detector closer to the source

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 159, 648, 175]]<|/det|>
B by placing an absorber between the detector and the source

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 185, 540, 201]]<|/det|>
C by repeating and averaging the measurements

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 211, 576, 227]]<|/det|>
D by taking away the background radiation count rate

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 255, 109, 273]]<|/det|>
<label>36</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 255, 709, 271]]<|/det|>
Which statement about alpha, beta and gamma radiation is not correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 283, 588, 299]]<|/det|>
A Alpha particles are deflected most in an electric field.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 310, 584, 325]]<|/det|>
B Beta particles are deflected most in a magnetic field.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 336, 594, 351]]<|/det|>
C Gamma radiation is not deflected by a magnetic field.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 362, 434, 377]]<|/det|>
D Gamma radiation is least ionising.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 405, 107, 424]]<|/det|>
<label>37</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 405, 634, 421]]<|/det|>
A sample of a radioactive material has a half-life of 20 minutes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 435, 350, 451]]<|/det|>
Which statement is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 463, 648, 479]]<|/det|>
A After 30 minutes, less than half of the material has decayed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 490, 650, 505]]<|/det|>
B After 40 minutes, all of the radioactive material has decayed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 516, 668, 531]]<|/det|>
C After 60 minutes, an eighth of the radioactive material remains.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 542, 658, 557]]<|/det|>
D After 120 minutes, a sixth of the radioactive material remains.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 586, 109, 604]]<|/det|>
<label>38</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 586, 350, 602]]<|/det|>
Which statement is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 615, 622, 630]]<|/det|>
A The Earth orbits the Sun once in approximately 24 hours.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 641, 622, 656]]<|/det|>
B The Earth orbits the Moon once in approximately 1 week.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 667, 630, 682]]<|/det|>
C The Moon orbits the Earth once in approximately 1 month.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 693, 626, 708]]<|/det|>
D The Sun orbits the Earth once in approximately 365 days.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 737, 107, 755]]<|/det|>
<label>39</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 737, 610, 753]]<|/det|>
Stars are powered by nuclear reactions that release energy.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 766, 638, 782]]<|/det|>
Which statement describes the nuclear reaction in stable stars?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 794, 534, 810]]<|/det|>
A Nuclear fission converts helium into hydrogen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 820, 534, 836]]<|/det|>
B Nuclear fission converts hydrogen into helium.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 847, 532, 862]]<|/det|>
C Nuclear fusion converts helium into hydrogen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 873, 532, 888]]<|/det|>
D Nuclear fusion converts hydrogen into helium.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>40</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 667, 88]]<|/det|>
A galaxy is moving away from the Earth at a velocity of 3000 km/s.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 103, 578, 119]]<|/det|>
What is the distance between the Earth and the galaxy?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 132, 262, 149]]<|/det|>
A \(7.3\times 10^{- 25}\mathrm{m}\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 160, 262, 176]]<|/det|>
B \(7.3\times 10^{- 22}\mathrm{m}\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 187, 255, 203]]<|/det|>
C \(1.4\times 10^{21}\mathrm{m}\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 214, 255, 230]]<|/det|>
D \(1.4\times 10^{24}\mathrm{m}\)
